text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with a hoisin barbecued ribs i have
to apologize for the horrible photos if
you've been reading the blog you know I
had a hard disk crash I lost all these
rib photos so anyway I got these really
bad screenshots which are all distorted
from the heat in the reflection but it
was a nice recipe so I'm going to show
it anyway so we're going to take one
whole pork spare rib I'm going to trim
off a little bit of the fat just
anything hanging you don't really want
to trim ribs too much all right then I'm
going to cut it in half just to make it
easier to marinade and kind of handle
throw it in a ziplock bag the big heavy
ones and we're going to get our marinade
ready which is hoisin sauce really
really interesting story as far as the
origins of hoisin sauce really
interesting
all right and some pineapple juice which
I had left over see this is just me
using stuff up in the kitchen so we got
holy sin we got pineapple a nice big
dollop of chili paste sambal give that a
little massage G and we're going to
marinate that squeeze out the air and
we're going to marinate that overnight
you can do with like eight hours six
hours but you know a day is good next
day I took it out of the fridge I'm
going to take it out of the marinade and
I'm going to Pat it dry so I can apply a
very simple dry rub all right so I have
that on my baking sheet the dry rub is
some fine sea salt some Chinese
five-spice powder brown sugar that I
spilled all over excuse me while I wipe
it up there we go some cayenne pepper
all right and we're going to mix that up
so very simple dry rub salt pepper sugar
as usual and the five-spice gives a
really nice aromatic kind of Asian aroma
and taste I'm going to pop that in a
300-degree oven for an hour while that's
roasting I'm going to get my basting
sauce together very easy ketchup rice
vinegar a little bit of soy sauce a
little bit of fish sauce and a little
shot of hoisin make it two shots awesome
all right we're going to mix that up
with my silicone basting brush you got
to get one of these if you're using
those old paintbrush with the bristles
and the hairs that fall out come on get
with the program after an hour I'm going
to take out the spare ribs from the oven
and I'm going to begin a long process of
building this glaze so about every 15
minutes I'm going to pull them out all
right I'm going to baste both sides with
the sauce I'm going to put it back in
the oven and I'm going to keep repeating
that so put it in 15 20 minutes pull it
out put some more on
put it back in 15 20 minutes pull it out
put some more on and what you'll do is
you build up a beautiful almost like a
lacquered nice hoisin Asian barbecue
style glaze so I did that kept it at 300
degrees which is a little hotter than I
normally cook ribs but I wanted the
outside to get a nice glaze so this went
about three and a half more hours now
this is where you really do it to your
personal
reference some people like chewy ribs
they have to pull the meat off the bones
some people like it just completely
falling off the bones I kind of like it
in-between I like it very tender I like
to be able to have it kind of come off
the bone with a little bit of effort but
I like it to come off the bone clean so
for me that was about you know four and
a half hours here's where I would
normally would have these amazing photos
just beautiful photos cut placed on a
plate
some Asian coleslaw and whatever but I
don't so you have to close your eyes and
imagine or you know what make it
yourself take some photos and send them
to me and I will repost it all right so
anyway give this a try go to the site
all the ingredients are there and as
always enjoy
